content: Hello! I make videos about mathematics, and in the video I'm currently working on I'd like to show a snippet of mathlib code (Euclid's proof of infinite primes). Does anyone know if this is ok, and how I should go about referencing it? I believe mathlib4 is released under Apache 2.0, but I'm not too sure of the implications for simply showing the code, rather than using it in software. There are also Microsoft copy rights at the header of each page, so I thought I'd ask to see if anyone knew how I should go about using this code. Thanks :D

Eyesomorphic said:

At the header of the mathlib4 lean file which contains Euclid's proof of infinite primes, it definitely says Microsoft copyright 2015, which makes me apprehensive about using it. Not sure what's up with that

That's just a common practice to identify the copyright owner (or at least who the committer believes is the owner), it doesn't change the terms of the license, and it doesn't mean that those particular files are not offered under the terms of the repo's license.

My sense is that the mathlib authors would be happy as long as you say what it is and don't try to pass it off as something else (your viewers will probably need a little bit of background anyway), but if you want to CYA and attempt to comply with the obligations imposed on licensees engaged in redistribution, you can include something like the following in your video's description "Mathlib4 is made available under the Apache-2.0 license: [copy and paste the contents of the LICENSE file]".
